TEXT.English: Cities with State Religion train units faster

[TAB]Manorialism is the organization of rural economy and society in medieval western and parts of central Europe, characterised by the vesting of legal and economic power in a lord supported economically from his own direct landholding and from the obligatory contributions of a legally subject part of the peasant population under his jurisdiction. These obligations could be payable in labour, produce ("in kind") or rarely money.[PARAGRAPH:2]The word derives from traditional inherited divisions of the countryside reassigned as local jurisdictions known as manors; each manor being subject to a lord, usually holding his position in return for undertakings offered to a higher lord. The lord held a manor court governed by public law and local custom. Not all territorial seigneurs were secular: bishops and abbots held lands that entailed similar obligations.

[TAB]A market economy allows the "market forces" of private supply and demand to determine prices of goods and services. Prices depend on both simple factors, like tastes and preferences for different kinds of products, and more complex factors, like expectations about future market conditions. Such an economy is dynamic and usually more efficient than economies that prioritise stability.[PARAGRAPH:2]Feudal economies were not market economies, because prices for labour were often set by law, and estates were often self-contained. Effective market institutions became more common as states brought down internal trade barriers and introduced standard weights and measures. Even so, markets were easily disrupted by currency shocks, like seignoirage and the Spanish discoveries of New World gold, and by bubbles like the Dutch tulip mania.

[TAB]A constitutional monarchy is a form of government in which a king or queen reigns with limits to their power along with a governing body (i.e. Parliament), giving rise to the modern adage "the Queen reigns but does not rule". In constitutional monarchies the position of monarch may be hereditary, hence the need for a royal family, or elected.[PARAGRAPH:2]The English monarchy is considered the oldest of modern constitutional monarchies, and the model for this form of government in the English-speaking world. A constitutional monarchy was able to form in England across different periods of history for a complex combination of reasons: sometimes due to a lack of strong leadership, and at other times due to strong leaders short of funding, who needed to raise money to prosecute wars, and needed to address public grievances to ensure this money was forthcoming.[PARAGRAPH:2]Historically, the English were divided on the question of the origins and justification for monarchy, but the Continental and Scottish belief in the "Divine Right of Kings" gradually gave ground to modern social-contract philosophy. The Magna Carta in 1215 is considered the first codification of the monarchy as a contract among territorial chiefs.

[TAB]In a republic, the head of state is not a monarch and there are no legal privileges for the nobility. The exact form of government can vary widely, from absolute despotism to direct democracy, but the most important difference between a republic and any form of monarchy is the much-diminished role of family and lineage in government.[PARAGRAPH:2]Before the French Revolution, a republic in Europe was an aberration. The state enjoyed none of the external security provided by royal family ties. Internally, the succession was decided to some extent by merit, even if this often meant merely that the man with the best ability to take power would do so.

[TAB]After the fall of Rome, Europe reverted to local rule by local rulers. Codes of laws were applied arbitrarily where they even existed. The ordinary person had no conception of rights, and no entitlement to such rights, even in theory.[PARAGRAPH:2]The philosopher Thomas Hobbes wrote that human life without government is a "war of all against all"; much the same can be said for arbitrary government. Society cannot enact higher concepts such as justice and fairness. And without property rights, individuals have no interest in making long-term investments whose payoff they will never enjoy.

[TAB]Feudal law is the framework within which most medieval European societies operated. Under feudalism, the individual's position in society depended on his family and his family's land, and these would stay the same from generation to generation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Each man, from peasant to king, owes certain basic duties to those above and below him in the chain. The vassal must swear fealty to his lord, and the lord must protect his vassal from others. Government power of every sort is highly decentralised. Though far from a system of equal rights under one law, feudalism did create a balance of power among the classes in which Europe operated until the rise of free cities and merchants in the High Middle Ages.

[TAB]Many organised religions have extensive codes or bodies of law to govern their internal affairs. In some societies, these legal systems are accepted as the principles which will govern the nation as a whole. A legal system in which religious principles determine secular law tends to mean an intermingling of the affairs of church and state.[PARAGRAPH:2]Canon law exists in those Christian churches with a centralised hierarchy, like Catholicism and Anglicanism. Though not widespread in Christendom, it did apply in religious communities instead of secular laws. The Islamic jurisprudence, or fiqh, has produced a body of work that lasts continuously from the time just after the Qur'an to the present day.

[TAB]Common law was developed by the English judiciary following the Norman conquest of 1066. Judges themselves were given great scope to develop the law beyond that set out by the legislature or executive. The term "common law" itself refers to legal precedent, the body of past decisions which are binding upon future cases.[PARAGRAPH:2]Common law allowed for reliable outcomes from the legal system even without a formal code of laws. This was of great use in early commercial economies, and the qualities of the system are shown in its resilience. To this day, in many countries which were once part of the British Empire, case law precedent (not parliamentary legislation) is the basis for the laws of contract and liability.

[TAB]Even when feudalism prevailed throughout Europe, there were subtle differences among the national systems. In countries like England, many or all peasants enjoyed great freedoms compared to their villein or serf counterparts. Certain taxes paid by the serfs were waived for the free peasants.[PARAGRAPH:2]Instead of owing labour services or the output of land, the free peasant paid a fixed rent to his lord. This allowed much greater freedom of action, for instance, in choosing which crops to grow or in alienating the land from his family. The existence of a free peasantry created social mobility which did not exist in other societies.

[TAB]Free labor is a system in which people do not owe a statutory duty to their employer to provide work. Work, pay, terms and conditions are determined by agreement or contract. Free labor excludes slavery, serfdom and other systems in which workers cannot end their employment.[PARAGRAPH:2]When workers can choose what they want to do every day, they can enjoy better wages and a better quality of life. Society as a whole is better-off when workers and employers match up freely rather than under coercion or by tradition. In modern Western societies, only military conscription survives as a legacy of the days of unfree labor.

[TAB]When the merchant class became powerful enough to influence public opinion by their actions, they sought to ensure the government would rule according to their interests. The landed aristocracy lost out as commercial goals often came into conflict with the desires of traditional domestic agriculture.[PARAGRAPH:2]Although this strife played itself out in many European states, it was in the republics of Venice and Genoa that mercantile oligarchies took power. Ruling councils ended feudal influence over taxation and spending. These states thrived on trade, but could not sustain the war economy common in medieval Europe without great cost to the interests of the government.

[TAB]Most medieval states practiced some form of state religion. Though a state may have been ruled by a king rather than a cleric, it was clear that the authority of the monarch derived from God. To deviate from the state religion was at best a faux pas, at worst a crime punishable by death.[PARAGRAPH:2]Christian Kings were crowned and anointed in a ceremony similar to the investiture of clergy with holy orders. Those same clergy sat in the medieval European parliaments and enjoyed the same official position as the highest ranks of nobility. In the early Islamic world, religious gatherings performed many functions of government.

[TAB]Kings often challenged the legitimacy of their neighbours to rule certain plots of land. Wars of conquest were common in Europe during the Middle Ages. But under the feudal system, conquest inevitably meant the destruction of the old government as the losing barons were punished. Some states managed to overcome this problem and created great empires.[PARAGRAPH:2]Successful imperialism required leaders to rapidly export systems of law and commerce to their non-national territories, so that anarchy would not prevail. It often took a long time for new subjects to overcome their loyalty to the old king and nation, and instead embrace the winner of war, so patience was a leading virtue of an asiprant emperor.

[TAB]Advances in naval technology allowed Europe to begin colonising the world around them in the late 15th century. Colonial adventures brought European rulers and technology to weak states. At the same time, colonialism introduced Europeans to the powerful states beyond the Islamic world.[PARAGRAPH:2]A colonial disposition manifested itself in dynamism of settlement and trade and a concentration on naval technology and investment. The change from an inward-looking to an outward-looking perspective created a new hierarchy of states based on colonial success and allowed Western Europe, with its access to the Atlantic, to surge ahead of the East.

[TAB]The guild system which developed in the late Middle Ages involved strict controls on employment in trades, so that the guild would enjoy monopoly market power. The apprenticeship system allowed control of numbers by requiring that a trainee craftsman associate himself with a "master" (the owner of a workshop) during and after his training, which could last for between five and ten years.[PARAGRAPH:2]Traders were prevented by law from working in a trade if they had not completed an apprenticeship. By requiring a master, commitment and cheap labour, the system successfully limited participation in industry, and delayed Europe's change from the traditional agricultural economy.

[TAB]Feudal monarchy spread across Europe in the wake of Charlemagne's empire. Kings and lesser lords were bound to each other by agreements to provide mutual assistance. The monarch guaranteed his authority to the execution of government functions by his vassals; in exchange, they agreed to provide the soldiers for the king's military adventures.[PARAGRAPH:2]In practice, feudal monarchies were quite diverse in the amount of authority given to vassals. The Kingdom of England was strong, but the weak Kingdom of France could not exert its power over its nominal vassals, like the Duchy of Burgundy. As kings centralised government authority, the traditional feudal monarchy declined. The last feudal government in Europe was on the island of Sark, which became a democracy only in 2008.

[TAB]The theory of divine monarchy, or the divine right of kings, holds that monarchs derive their legitimacy from the will of God, and that any limitation of the king's power is therefore against the will of God. This provided a justification for absolute monarchs of Western Europe to overrule other social groups, including the nobility and the church itself.[PARAGRAPH:2]The doctrine was popular among both Protestant and Catholic kings, and similar concepts existed elsewhere. The common thread was simply that they sought to govern without regard to the will of the established and often powerful elite classes.
+1 stability for each colony founded.
Expansion
TEXT.French: Expansion
TEXT.Italian: Espansione
TEXT.Spanish: Expansión

TEXT.English: Subjugation
TEXT.French: Assujettissement
TEXT.Italian: Sottomissione
TEXT.Spanish: Subyugación

TEXT.English: [TAB]The term "subjugation" is used to describe the policy of a nation's dominance over other lands. This doctrine has been frequently employed for economic exploitation in which an imperialist power makes use of other countries as sources of raw materials and cheap labor, shaping their economies to suit its own interests and keeping their people in poverty. [PARAGRAPH:2]Sometimes subjugation even refers to the acceptance, by the colonised, of the culture or doctrines of the coloniser as intrinsically more worthy or superior.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le terme d'Assujettissement fait référence à la politique de dominance d'une nation. Cette doctrine a souvent été employée pour l'exploitation économique d'un pays par un autre : un pouvoir impérialiste utilise d'autres pays en tant que sources de matières premières et de main-d'oeuvre bon marché, ajuste leur économie selon ses propres intérêts et maintient les gens dans la pauvreté. [PARAGRAPH:2]Parfois, l'Assujettissement fait référence à l'acceptation par les peuples colonisés de la culture ou des doctrines des colonisateurs, considérées comme meilleures ou supérieures.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff "Unterwerfung" beschreibt die politischen Bestrebungen einer Nation, andere Länder beherrschen zu wollen. Diese Doktrin wurde häufig zur Realisierung wirtschaftlicher Ausbeutung eingesetzt, wobei die Kolonialmacht andere Länder als Quellen für seltene Rohstoffe und billige Arbeitskräfte missbrauchte, deren Wirtschaft sie dann so gestaltete, dass sie zu den eigenen Interessen passte und schlussendlich die Einheimischen in ihrer Armut beließ. [PARAGRAPH:2]Manchmal wird mit "Unterwerfung" allerdings auch der Umstand bezeichnet, dass die Kolonisierten die Kultur oder Lehren der Kolonialmacht als "wertvoller" oder "besser" akzeptieren und würdigen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il termine "sottomissione" viene usato per descrivere il dominio di una nazione su altre terre. Questa dottrina è stata spesso usata per lo sfruttamento economico: una potenza imperialista sfrutta altri paesi come fonti di materie prime e lavoro a basso costo, modellando le loro economie a favore dei propri interessei e mantenendone le popolazioni in povertà. [PARAGRAPH:2]Alle volte la sottomissione fa addirittura riferimento all'accettazione, da parte dei colonizzati, di una presunta e intrinseca superiorità della cultura dei colonizzatori.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El término "subyugación" se utiliza para describir la política de dominio de una nación sobre otros territorios. Esta doctrina se ha empleado frecuentemente para describir la explotación económica que realiza una potencia imperialista cuando utiliza a otros países como fuentes de materias primas y mano de obra barata, modelando sus economías según sus propios intereses y manteniendo a sus gentes en la pobreza. [PARAGRAPH:2]A veces la subyugación también alude a la aceptación por parte de la colonia de la cultura o las doctrinas de la potencia colonial como intrínsecamente superiores.
TEXT.Russian: [TAB]The term "subjugation" is used to describe the policy of a nation's dominance over other lands. This doctrine has been frequently employed for economic exploitation in which an imperialist power makes use of other countries as sources of raw materials and cheap labor, shaping their economies to suit its own interests and keeping their people in poverty. [PARAGRAPH:2]Sometimes subjugation even refers to the acceptance, by the colonised, of the culture or doctrines of the coloniser as intrinsically more worthy or superior.

TEXT.English: Vassalage
TEXT.French: Vassalité
TEXT.Italian: Vicereame
TEXT.Spanish: Virreinato

TEXT.English: [TAB]A viceroy is a royal official who governs a country or province in the name of and as representative of a monarch. The term derives from the Latin prefix vice-, meaning "in the place of" and French roi, meaning king. His province or territory is called a viceroyalty. [PARAGRAPH:2]The title was originally used by the Aragonese Crown during the 14th Century to refer to Sardinia and Corsica. The absolutist Kings of Spain employed numerous Viceroys to rule over various parts of their vast empire "where the sun never sets", both European and overseas.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un vice-roi est un représentant royal qui gouverne un pays ou une province en tant que représentant d'un monarque. Il s'agit de la personne qui agit "à la place de" ("vice-") son roi. Sa province ou son territoire est appelée vice-royauté. [PARAGRAPH:2]Ce titre était utilisé à l'origine par la Couronne d'Aragon, durant le 14e siècle, pour désigner la Sardaigne et la Corse. Les monarques espagnols nommaient de nombreux vice-rois, afin de régner sur les différentes régions de leur vaste empire, "où le soleil ne se couche jamais", en Europe et par-delà les océans.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Vizekönig ist ein königlicher Würdenträger, der ein Land oder eine Provinz im Namen bzw. als Repräsentant des Königs regiert. Der Begriff ist von der lateinischen Vorsilbe "Vize" (an Stelle von) abgeleitet. Seine Provinz bzw. seine Ländereien werden Vizekönigreich genannt. [PARAGRAPH:2]Ursprünglich wurde dieser Titel seit dem 14. Jahrhundert vom Aragonischen Königshaus für Sardinien und Korsika verwendet. Die absolutistischen Könige Spaniens setzten unzählige Vizekönige ein, um die Kontrolle über weite Teile ihres riesigen Reiches, "in dem die Sonne niemals untergeht", sowohl in Europa als auch in Übersee zu sichern.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un viceré è un funzionario reale che governa un Paese o una provincia nel nome e come rappresentante di un monarca. Il termine deriva dal prefisso latino vice-, che significa "al posto di" e dal francese roi, che significa re. La provincia o il territorio controllato si chiama vicereame. [PARAGRAPH:2]Il titolo venne originariamente usato dalla corona di Aragona, durante il 14° secolo, in riferimento a Sardegna e Corsica. I monarchi assoluti di Spagna usarono numerosi viceré per governare diverse parti del loro vasto impero, "su cui non tramonta mai il sole", sia in Europa che oltremare.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un virrey es un delegado real que gobierna un país o una provincia en nombre de un monarca. El término deriva del latín "vice regis", que quiere decir "en nombre del rey". Su provincia o territorio se denomina "virreinato". [PARAGRAPH:2]El título lo utilizó originalmente la corona de Aragón durante el siglo XIV para aludir a Córcega y Cerdeña. Los reyes absolutistas españoles emplearon numerosos virreyes para gestionar su vasto imperio, tanto europeo como de ultramar, "en el que nunca se ponía el sol".

TEXT.English: Imperialism
TEXT.French: Imperialisme
TEXT.Italian: Risistemazione
TEXT.Spanish: Reasentamiento

TEXT.English: [TAB]"Resettlement" literally means the transportation of a group of people to a new settlement and the populating of a new area. Although migration has featured throughout human history and prehistory, the word settler (synonymous with terms like pioneers and colonists) is often used in relation to modern or early modern history. [PARAGRAPH:2]The reason for emigration of settlers varies, but often includes one or more factors such as: personal economic hardship; social, cultural, ethnic, or religious persecution; political oppression; or policies aimed at encouraging foreign settlement.
TEXT.French: [TAB]"Repeuplement" signifie littéralement amener un groupe de personnes dans une nouvelle implantation pour peupler une zone. Bien que la migration soit une constante de la préhistoire et de l'histoire de l'humanité, le mot colon (synonyme de pionnier) est souvent utilisé en relation avec l'histoire moderne ou contemporaine. [PARAGRAPH:2]Les raisons qui poussent à émigrer sont nombreuses, mais on retrouve souvent les difficultés économiques personnelles, les persécutions sociales, ethniques ou religieuses, l'oppression politique, ou des politiques encourageant la colonisation.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff "Umsiedlung" beschreibt den Umzug einer Gruppe von Menschen in ein neues Siedlungsgebiet bzw. die Bevölkerung neuer Gebiete. Während es derartige "Völkerwanderungen" in der gesamten Menschheitsgeschichte gegeben hat, wird der davon abgeleitete Begriff "Siedler" (Synonym für Pionier und Kolonist) häufig in Bezug auf die moderne bzw. frühmoderne Geschichte verwendet. [PARAGRAPH:2]Es gibt unterschiedliche Gründe für die Ab- bzw. Auswanderung von Siedlern, meist spielen dabei jedoch folgende Faktoren eine Rolle: persönliches bzw. wirtschaftliches Elend, soziale, kulturelle, ethnische oder religiöse Verfolgung, politische Unterdrückung oder die politische Förderung fremder Siedlungen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]"Risistemazione" sta a indicare il trasporto di un gruppo di persone in un nuovo insediamento e il popolamento di una nuova zona. Anche se le migrazioni hanno avuto luogo in tutta la storia e preistoria umana, la parola colonizzatore (o anche pioniere o colono) è spesso utilizzata in relazione alla storia moderna. [PARAGRAPH:2]Le ragioni per l'emigrazione dei coloni sono diverse, ma spesso includono uno o più fattori come: forti problemi economici; persecuzione sociale, culturale, etnica o religiosa; oppressione politica, oppure politiche che incoraggiano l'insediamento all'estero.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El "reasentamiento" consiste en el traslado de un grupo de personas a un nuevo enclave para poblar una nueva zona. Aunque la migración ha existido en toda la historia, e incluso en la prehistoria, el término colono, en ocasiones sinónimo de pionero, se suele utilizar en contextos de la historia moderna o contemporánea. [PARAGRAPH:2]Los motivos de la migración colonial son variados, pero a menudo incluyen dos o más factores, como penurias económicas, persecución social, cultural, étnica o religiosa, opresión política o políticas potenciadoras de la emigración o la inmigración.
TEXT.Russian: [TAB]"Resettlement" literally means the transportation of a group of people to a new settlement and the populating of a new area. Although migration has featured throughout human history and prehistory, the word settler (synonymous with terms like pioneers and colonists) is often used in relation to modern or early modern history. [PARAGRAPH:2]The reason for emigration of settlers varies, but often includes one or more factors such as: personal economic hardship; social, cultural, ethnic, or religious persecution; political oppression; or policies aimed at encouraging foreign settlement.

TEXT.English: Occupation
TEXT.French: Occupation
TEXT.Italian: Occupazione
TEXT.Spanish: Ocupación

TEXT.English: [TAB]Belligerent military occupation occurs when one nation's military occupies all or part of the territory of another nation or recognized belligerent. [PARAGRAPH:2]In most wars some territory of the losing side is placed under the authority of the hostile army. Most military occupations end with the cessation of hostilities. In some cases the occupied territory is returned and in others the land remains under the control of the occupying power but usually not as militarily occupied territory. The latter was the case of Germany after WWII, which ended up being split into two different nations.
TEXT.French: [TAB]L'occupation militaire désigne la présence d'une armée étrangère sur tout ou partie du territoire d'une autre nation ou d'un belligérant reconnu. [PARAGRAPH:2]Dans la plupart des guerres, certains territoires du pays vaincu sont placés sous l'autorité d'une armée ennemie. La plupart des occupations militaires se terminent avec la cessation des hostilités. Dans certains cas, le territoire occupé est rendu et dans d'autres, il reste sous le contrôle de la puissance occupante, mais plus en tant que territoire occupé militairement. La dernière occupation fut celle de l'Allemagne après la Seconde Guerre mondiale, qui se termina par sa division en deux pays distincts.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine kriegerische militärische Besatzung tritt dann ein, wenn die militärischen Streitkräfte einer Nation das Territorium einer anderen Nation oder eines Kriegsgegners vollständig oder teilweise besetzen. [PARAGRAPH:2]In den meisten Kriegen wurde ein Teil des Territoriums der Verliererseite der Befehlsgewalt der feindlichen Militärs unterstellt. Dabei beendeten die militärischen Besatzungen in der Regel gleichzeitig auch die Feindseligkeiten zwischen den Kriegsparteien. In manchen Fällen wurde das Besatzungsgebiet später wieder zurückgegeben, in anderen verblieb es in der Hand der Besatzungsmacht, normalerweise aber nicht mehr als militärisch besetztes Territorium. Letzteres ereignete sich nach dem 2. Weltkrieg in Deutschland und endete damit, dass Deutschland bis zur Wiedervereinigung im Jahr 1990 in zwei verschiedene Staaten aufgeteilt war.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'occupazione militare si ha quando l'esercito di una nazione occupa tutto o parte del territorio di un'altra nazione o fazione ostile. [PARAGRAPH:2]In molte guerre parte del territorio della fazione perdente viene posto sotto l'autorità dell'esercito ostile. La maggior parte delle occupazioni militari terminano con la cessazione delle ostilità. In alcuni casi il territorio occupato viene restituito, mentre in altri rimane sotto il controllo della potenza occupante, anche se solitamente non come territorio occupato militarmente. Questo fu il caso della Germania dopo la Seconda Guerra Mondiale, che finì con l'essere divisa in due diverse nazioni.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La ocupación militar se produce cuando un ejército beligerante de una nación ocupa todo o parte del territorio de otra nación. [PARAGRAPH:2]En muchas guerras, parte del territorio del bando derrotado es sometido a la autoridad del ejército hostil. La mayor parte de las ocupaciones militares finalizan con el cese de las hostilidades. En algunos casos, el territorio ocupado es devuelto, pero en otros la zona permanece bajo control de la potencia enemiga, aunque ya no como territorio ocupado militarmente. El último fue el caso de Alemania tras la II Guerra Mundial, que acabó siendo divida entre dos naciones diferentes.
TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Belligerent military occupation occurs when one nation's military occupies all or part of the territory of another nation or recognized belligerent. [PARAGRAPH:2]In most wars some territory of the losing side is placed under the authority of the hostile army. Most military occupations end with the cessation of hostilities. In some cases the occupied territory is returned and in others the land remains under the control of the occupying power but usually not as militarily occupied territory. The latter was the case of Germany after WWII, which ended up being split into two different nations.

TEXT.English: Colonialism
TEXT.French: Colonialisme
TEXT.Italian: Commonwealth
TEXT.Spanish: Commonwealth

TEXT.English: [TAB]The English noun "Commonwealth" originally dates from the fifteenth century. The term literally meant "common well-being". Thus commonwealth originally meant a state governed for the common good as opposed to an authoritarian state governed for the benefit of a given class of owners. [PARAGRAPH:2]Today the term is more general and means a political community. When capitalised, "Commonwealth" normally refers to the 53 member Commonwealth of Nations - formerly the "British Commonwealth" - a loose confederation of nations formerly members of the British Empire.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le terme anglais "Commonwealth" remonte au quinzième siècle. Il signifie littéralement "bien-être de tous". Commonwealth voulait donc désigner un état gouverné pour le bien de tous, par opposition à un état autoritaire gouverné pour le bénéfice d'une certaine classe possédante. [PARAGRAPH:2]Aujourd'hui, le terme est plus général et désigne une communauté politique. Le Commonwealth fait normalement référence aux 53 nations qui faisaient à l'origine partie du Commonwealth britannique, une confédération disparate de pays issus de l'ancien empire britannique.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der englische Begriff "Commonwealth" datiert ursprünglich aus dem 15. Jahrhundert und bedeutet wörtlich übersetzt etwa "Gemeinwohl". Er bezeichnete ursprünglich einen Staat, dessen Regierung vornehmlich auf das Wohl der Gemeinschaft abzielt, im Gegensatz zum autoritären Staat, dessen Regierung vor allem auf das Wohlergehen einer bestimmten Klasse von Grundbesitzern und sonstigen Eigentümern hinarbeitet. [PARAGRAPH:2]Heute wird der Begriff allgemeiner verwendet und beschreibt eine politische Staatengemeinschaft. Wenn man vom "Commonwealth" spricht, ist damit nun normalerweise das aus 53 Mitgliedsstaaten gebildete "Commonwealth of Nations" - ehemals "British Commonwealth" genannt - gemeint, ein freiwilliger Bund unabhängiger Staaten, die früher zum British Empire gehörten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La parola inglese "Commonwealth" risale al quindicesimo secolo. Il termine significava letteralmente "benessere comune". Quindi originariamente commonwealth stava a indicare uno stato governato per il bene comune, in opposizione a uno stato autoritario governato per il benessere di una data classe. [PARAGRAPH:2]Oggi il termine è più generico e indica una comunità politica. Quando è maiuscolo, "Commonwealth" di solito si riferisce al Commonwealth delle Nazioni, composto da 53 membri e una volta conosciuto come Commonwealth britannico: una confederazione di nazioni che facevano precedentemente parte dell'impero britannico.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El término inglés "Commonwealth", que tiene su origen en el siglo XV, significa literalmente "bienestar común", y en sus orígenes hacía referencia a un tipo de estado cuyo gobierno persigue el bien común, frente a un estado autoritario que persigue el beneficio de una determinada clase social. [PARAGRAPH:2]Hoy el término es más general y alude a una comunidad política. Cuando se escribe con mayúsculas, "Commonwealth" hace referencia a la "Commonwealth of Nations" de 53 miembros, antes denominada "British Commonwealth of Nations", una confederación laxa que engloba a las naciones que pertenecieron al Imperio Británico.

TEXT.English: [ICON_BULLET]+4 Stability Points for each vassal
